articles.headline: India’s Restaurants Rebel Against Food Delivery Apps
articles.snippet: Frustrated by the steep commissions and discounts that apps like Zomato and Uber Eats push on restaurants, thousands have started a movement to #Logout from them.
articles.abstract: Frustrated by the steep commissions and discounts that apps like Zomato and Uber Eats push on restaurants, thousands have started a movement to #Logout from them.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — Aakanksha Porwal, the owner of a small retro diner called Vahnilla & Company, recently signed up for the Zomato food delivery app to make dishes like her veggie cheeseburgers and Kit Kat cakesicles available to a wider audience. She also joined Zomato’s Gold program, where she would offer two dishes for the price of one to members who came to dine in person.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and Ayesha Venkataraman

articles.headline: How 4 Companies Struggle to Navigate Trump’s Trade Uncertainty
articles.snippet: The president’s whiplash-inducing China moves over the past week sent companies across the United States scrambling to adjust.
articles.abstract: The president’s whiplash-inducing China moves over the past week sent companies across the United States scrambling to adjust.
articles.lead_paragraph: Executives at Columbia Sportswear in Portland, Ore., were in a high-level meeting last Friday to wrap up their response to the Trump administration’s latest round of tariffs on Chinese imports when the president took to Twitter.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley, Alan Rappeport and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: 15 Minutes to ‘Mayhem’: How a Tweet Led to a Shortage at Popeyes
articles.snippet: The “chicken sandwich wars” with Chick-fil-A captivated the internet and drove record sales. Then they became a logistical headache.
articles.abstract: The “chicken sandwich wars” with Chick-fil-A captivated the internet and drove record sales. Then they became a logistical headache.
articles.lead_paragraph: They started a war in 15 minutes.
articles.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Matthew Sedacca

articles.headline: In Iran’s Hierarchy, Talks With Trump Are Now Seen as Inevitable
articles.snippet: Iranian leaders have concluded that President Trump could win a second term and they will have to deal with him.
articles.abstract: Iranian leaders have concluded that President Trump could win a second term and they will have to deal with him.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the power circles of Tehran, where “Death to America” is regularly chanted, the idea has taken hold that Iran must eventually negotiate with President Trump, according to several people with knowledge of the shift.

articles.headline: How Kirsten Gillibrand’s Presidential Dreams Unraveled
articles.snippet: The New York senator ran as the champion of feminism, but her message did not break through in a field with six women. With little money left and no place on the debate stage, she decided to drop out.
articles.abstract: The New York senator ran as the champion of feminism, but her message did not break through in a field with six women. With little money left and no place on the debate stage, she decided to drop out.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Kirsten Gillibrand was in a bind.

articles.headline: Pete Buttigieg Was Rising. Then Came South Bend’s Policing Crisis.
articles.snippet: He spent years focusing on his city’s economic record but it is his record on policing, once a footnote, that is overshadowing his presidential campaign.
articles.abstract: He spent years focusing on his city’s economic record but it is his record on policing, once a footnote, that is overshadowing his presidential campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOUTH BEND, Ind. — On a Tuesday in March, just after Pete Buttigieg began to catch fire with Democrats nationally, he flew home for his final State of the City address.
articles.byline: By Trip Gabriel and Richard A. Oppel Jr

articles.headline: With ‘Talking to Strangers,’ Malcolm Gladwell Goes Dark
articles.snippet: Read by millions — but savaged by critics — the author has a new book on police violence, campus rape and other bleak terrain.
articles.abstract: Read by millions — but savaged by critics — the author has a new book on police violence, campus rape and other bleak terrain.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the weeks I spent listening to Malcolm Gladwell’s podcast, I learned that lobsters have serotonin, that Elvis Presley suffered from parapraxis and that Mr. Gladwell adheres to a firm life rule that he drink only five liquids: water, tea, red wine, espresso and milk.

articles.headline: China Expels Wall Street Journal Reporter After Article on Xi’s Cousin
articles.snippet: Beijing declined to renew the credentials of a reporter who wrote about an investigation in Australia involving a cousin of China’s leader, Xi Jinping.
articles.abstract: Beijing declined to renew the credentials of a reporter who wrote about an investigation in Australia involving a cousin of China’s leader, Xi Jinping.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China has effectively expelled a reporter working for The Wall Street Journal after he wrote an article about an investigation in Australia involving a cousin of China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, in the latest sign of a government clampdown on media freedom.

articles.headline: Beijing’s Hong Kong Strategy: More Arrests, No Concessions
articles.snippet: Officials say that many more demonstrators will face charges, and that none of their movement’s demands will be met.
articles.abstract: Officials say that many more demonstrators will face charges, and that none of their movement’s demands will be met.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The arrests on Friday of prominent democracy lawmakers and activists in Hong Kong reflect a tactical escalation by China’s leaders to curb the recent street violence, but which could prolong the protests for many months.
